trans-unit.source: How to view and change hostnames for Azure virtual machines, web and worker roles for name resolution
trans-unit.target: How to view and change hostnames for Azure virtual machines, web and worker roles for name resolution

trans-unit.source: Viewing and modifying hostnames
trans-unit.target: Viewing and modifying hostnames

trans-unit.source: To allow your role instances to be referenced by host name, you must set the value for the host name in the service configuration file for each role.
trans-unit.target: To allow your role instances to be referenced by host name, you must set the value for the host name in the service configuration file for each role.

trans-unit.source: You do that by adding the desired host name to the **vmName** attribute of the **Role** element.
trans-unit.target: You do that by adding the desired host name to the **vmName** attribute of the **Role** element.

trans-unit.source: The value of the **vmName** attribute is used as a base for the host name of each role instance.
trans-unit.target: The value of the **vmName** attribute is used as a base for the host name of each role instance.

trans-unit.source: For example, if **vmName** is *webrole* and there are three instances of that role, the host names of the instances will be *webrole0*, *webrole1*, and *webrole2*.
trans-unit.target: For example, if **vmName** is *webrole* and there are three instances of that role, the host names of the instances will be *webrole0*, *webrole1*, and *webrole2*.

trans-unit.source: You do not need to specify a host name for virtual machines in the configuration file, because the host name for a virtual machine is populated based on the virtual machine name.For more information about configuring a Microsoft Azure service, see [Azure Service Configuration Schema (.cscfg File)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee758710.aspx)
trans-unit.target: You do not need to specify a host name for virtual machines in the configuration file, because the host name for a virtual machine is populated based on the virtual machine name.For more information about configuring a Microsoft Azure service, see [Azure Service Configuration Schema (.cscfg File)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee758710.aspx)

trans-unit.source: Viewing hostnames
trans-unit.target: Viewing hostnames

trans-unit.source: You can view the host names of virtual machines and role instances in a cloud service by using various tools: Azure portal, service configuration file, Remote Desktop, and [Azure Service Management REST API](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee460799.aspx).
trans-unit.target: You can view the host names of virtual machines and role instances in a cloud service by using various tools: Azure portal, service configuration file, Remote Desktop, and [Azure Service Management REST API](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee460799.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Azure Portal
trans-unit.target: Azure Portal

trans-unit.source: You can use the Azure portal to view the host names for virtual machines on the virtual machine dashboard page.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Azure portal to view the host names for virtual machines on the virtual machine dashboard page.

trans-unit.source: Keep in mind that the dashboard shows a value for **Name** and **Host Name**.
trans-unit.target: Keep in mind that the dashboard shows a value for **Name** and **Host Name**.

trans-unit.source: Although they are initially the same, changing the host name will not change the name of the virtual machine or role instance.
trans-unit.target: Although they are initially the same, changing the host name will not change the name of the virtual machine or role instance.

trans-unit.source: Role instances can also be located in the Azure portal, but when you list the instances in a cloud service, the host name is not displayed.
trans-unit.target: Role instances can also be located in the Azure portal, but when you list the instances in a cloud service, the host name is not displayed.

trans-unit.source: You will see a name for each instance, but that name does not represent the host name.
trans-unit.target: You will see a name for each instance, but that name does not represent the host name.

trans-unit.source: Service configuration file
trans-unit.target: Service configuration file

trans-unit.source: You can download the service configuration file for a deployed service from the **Configure** page of the service in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: You can download the service configuration file for a deployed service from the **Configure** page of the service in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: You can then look for the **vmName** attribute for the **Role name** element to see the host name.
trans-unit.target: You can then look for the **vmName** attribute for the **Role name** element to see the host name.

trans-unit.source: Keep in mind that this host name is used as a base for the host name of each role instance.
trans-unit.target: Keep in mind that this host name is used as a base for the host name of each role instance.

trans-unit.source: For example, if **vmName** is *webrole* and there are three instances of that role, the host names of the instances will be *webrole0*, *webrole1*, and *webrole2*.
trans-unit.target: For example, if **vmName** is *webrole* and there are three instances of that role, the host names of the instances will be *webrole0*, *webrole1*, and *webrole2*.

trans-unit.source: Remote Desktop
trans-unit.target: Remote Desktop

trans-unit.source: After you enable Remote Desktop (Windows), Windows PowerShell remoting (Windows), or SSH (Linux and Windows) connections to your virtual machines or role instances, you can view the host name from an active Remote Desktop connection in various ways:
trans-unit.target: After you enable Remote Desktop (Windows), Windows PowerShell remoting (Windows), or SSH (Linux and Windows) connections to your virtual machines or role instances, you can view the host name from an active Remote Desktop connection in various ways:

trans-unit.source: Type hostname at the command prompt or SSH terminal.
trans-unit.target: Type hostname at the command prompt or SSH terminal.

trans-unit.source: Type ipconfig /all at the command prompt (Windows only).
trans-unit.target: Type ipconfig /all at the command prompt (Windows only).

trans-unit.source: View the computer name in the system settings (Windows only).
trans-unit.target: View the computer name in the system settings (Windows only).

trans-unit.source: Azure Service Management REST API
trans-unit.target: Azure Service Management REST API

trans-unit.source: From a REST client, follow these instructions:
trans-unit.target: From a REST client, follow these instructions:

trans-unit.source: Ensure that you have a client certificate to connect to the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that you have a client certificate to connect to the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: To obtain a client certificate, follow the steps presented in [How to: Download and Import Publish Settings and Subscription Information](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn385850(v=nav.70).aspx).
trans-unit.target: To obtain a client certificate, follow the steps presented in [How to: Download and Import Publish Settings and Subscription Information](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn385850(v=nav.70).aspx).

trans-unit.source: Set a header entry named x-ms-version with a value of 2013-11-01.
trans-unit.target: Set a header entry named x-ms-version with a value of 2013-11-01.

trans-unit.source: Send a request in the following format: https://management.core.windows.net/\<subscrition-id\>/services/hostedservices/\<service-name\>?embed-detail=true
trans-unit.target: Send a request in the following format: https://management.core.windows.net/\<subscrition-id\>/services/hostedservices/\<service-name\>?embed-detail=true

trans-unit.source: Look for the **HostName** element for each **RoleInstance** element.
trans-unit.target: Look for the **HostName** element for each **RoleInstance** element.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.WARNING] You can also view the internal domain suffix for your cloud service from the REST call response by checking the **InternalDnsSuffix** element, or by running ipconfig /all from a command prompt in a Remote Desktop session (Windows), or by running cat /etc/resolv.conf from an SSH terminal (Linux).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.WARNING] You can also view the internal domain suffix for your cloud service from the REST call response by checking the **InternalDnsSuffix** element, or by running ipconfig /all from a command prompt in a Remote Desktop session (Windows), or by running cat /etc/resolv.conf from an SSH terminal (Linux).

trans-unit.source: Modifying a hostname
trans-unit.target: Modifying a hostname

trans-unit.source: You can modify the host name for any virtual machine or role instance by uploading a modified service configuration file, or by renaming the computer from a Remote Desktop session.
trans-unit.target: You can modify the host name for any virtual machine or role instance by uploading a modified service configuration file, or by renaming the computer from a Remote Desktop session.
